column13: Sustainability Certificates are based on independently verified studies of ISO 14040 LCA and ISO 14044 LCA standards. Customers use them for internal and external communications to demonstrate sustainable actions in their supply chains.

column6: New suppliers that were screened using environmental criteria
Negative environmental impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: Creation of new timber sources in degraded regions by partnering with various organisations to promote sustainable agroforestry practices. Critically, this fosters nature-connected socio-economic opportunities in local communities while contributing to Brambles' medium and longer-term raw material supply.
column20: Sustainable timber sources, Agroforestry, Community engagement

column6: Negative environmental impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: Certifying new sources of timber is challenging in some areas due to the need for certification systems. Brambles' procurement team developed the Fast Track to Certification (FT2C) programme, which has been successful in Brazil and Zimbabwe. FT2C leverages CHEP's experience with timber certification to accelerate the transition to certified sources with future suppliers aligned with our sustainable standards and seeking to become part of our supply ecosystem.
column20: Timber certification, Fast track programme, Sustainable procurement

column6: Minimum notice periods regarding operational changes
Occupation health and safety management system
column13: Brambles' Zero Harm Charter emphasises that everyone has the right to be safe at work and return home as healthy as they started the day. This approach includes Brambles' Feel Good programme to support mental wellbeing.
column20: Workplace safety, Mental wellbeing, Zero Harm Charter

column6: Occupation health and safety management system
column13: Safety First roadmap is based on three key phases, each designed to help navigate Brambles towards a vision of Zero Harm. Phase 1 2021 Re-setting the framework Safety Strategy: Phase 1 has yielded positive results, reflected in the lower incident statistics. Phase 2 2023 Broad consultation to establish the critical elements required for the next stage of our Strategy. Embed and mature elements of Phase 1 and build capability within our workplace community. Phase 3 2025 and beyond Passionate about continuous improvement.
column20: Safety roadmap, Incident reduction, Continuous improvement

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: Brambles IT developed a new process for monitoring performance, using leading indicators for safety, and bringing proactive safety efforts into clear view. This tool brings a refreshing blend of lagging and leading performance visuals to apply focus on critical priorities and to identify improvement opportunities. It also makes it easier for employees to report concerns about safety hazards and near-miss events.
column20: Safety monitoring, Leading indicators, Proactive reporting

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: A concept-to-completion approach (C2C) is now being used to ensure that Safety First principles are included throughout the lifecycle of large engineering projects.
column20: Safety in engineering, Lifecycle approach, Workplace safety

column6: Occupational health services
column13: Fixed barriers between mobile vehicles or equipment and pedestrians at Brambles' service centres have been a long-term top priority to ensure a safe workplace environment. The team have developed a new assessment and tracking tool to measure compliance status.
column20: Workplace barriers, Safety compliance, Workplace safety

column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column13: Improving culture and conditions is critical to a safe working environment; in FY23, the Operations Excellence team (supported by HSE) developed a global programme to deploy 5S in all service centre operations. Brambles 5S: Sort, Straighten, Shine, Standardise, Sustain.

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety

column7: Brambles has established a cross-functional Wellbeing Steering Committee with executive sponsorship, recognising that safety begins with a healthy mindset. Looking ahead, Brambles Global Wellbeing strategy, shaping 2027 and beyond, will launch in early FY24 with an exciting new calendar of development programmes.\t

column6: Promotion of worker health

column13: This year's safety week focused on the launch of SLAM, Brambles' new Situation Awareness approach to safety. SLAM is used to identify safety risks and has been adopted by other departments, including Cyber Safety and Wellbeing.

Average hours of training per year per employee
Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: 4,218 individuals completed one or more learning programmes, mainly in areas such as Digital and data Leadership (398 leaders trained), Advanced Analytics (1,164 completions), and Data Literacy (3,264 completions). The training was divided into two parts. The first session provided a theoretical foundation, including principles of corporate sustainability, regeneration, climate change and circular economy, and how these concepts align with our goals. The second session focused on practical implementation. Leaders were equipped with the necessary skills and tools to integrate sustainability into their daily practices and communication.

column13: In FY23, the business established a Global DEI team. This team now provides dedicated support to achieving our targets, streamlining our processes, and aligning regional activities with our global Strategy. This investment underscores our commitment to creating an international community where our people can coexist while celebrating what makes them unique and different.
